column4: or Stanisławów; see below) is a historic city located in Western Ukraine. It is the administrative centre of Ivano-Frankivsk Oblast. Administratively
column5: it is designated as a city of regional significance within the oblast
column6: and together with a number of rural localities
column7: is incorporated as Ivano-Frankivsk Municipality. Population: 237

column1: Built in the mid-17th century as a fortress of the Polish Potocki family
column2: Stanisławów was annexed to the Habsburg Empire during the First Partition of Poland in 1772
column3: after which it became the property of the State within the Austrian Empire. The fortress was slowly transformed into one of the most prominent cities at the foothills of the Carpathian Mountains. After World War I
column5: it served as a temporary capital of the West Ukrainian People's Republic. Following Peace of Riga
column6: Stanisławów became part of the Second Polish Republic. After the Soviet invasion of Poland at the onset of World War II
column7: the city was annexed by the Soviet Union
column8: only to be occupied by Nazi Germany two years later. With the liberation of Soviet Ukraine in 1944 and the shifting of borders
column9: the Communist regime ran the city for the next four-and-a-half decades. A few years before the fall of the Soviet Union
column10: the blue-yellow flag was raised in the city as the symbol of an independent Ukraine.

column1: A city visitor may find elements of various cultures intertwined within Ivano-Frankivsk

column5: and others. Ivano-Frankivsk is also one of the principal cities of the Carpathian Euroregion.

column1: Stanisławów was founded as a fortress and was named after the Polish hetman Stanisław "Rewera" Potocki. Some sources claim it was named after his grandson Stanisław. Following the First Partition of Poland in 1772
column2: the name was transliterated as Stanislau in German
column3: as the city became part of the Austrian Empire (future Austria-Hungary); however
column5: the city carried three different linguistic renderings of its name: German
column12: pronounced [stɐnɪˈslɑwiu̯]). Other spellings used in the local press media included Russian: Станиславов and Yiddish: סטאַניסלאוו‎.

column1: After World War II it was changed by the Soviet authorities into a simplified version Stanislav (Ukrainian: Станісла́в
column5: it was renamed to honor the Ukrainian writer Ivan Franko. Due to the city's wordy name
column6: unofficially it is sometimes called simply Franyk (Франик) by its residents. Even though Ivano-Frankivsk is the officially accepted name
column7: the city's original name has never been fully abandoned and/or forgotten and can be found throughout the city in all kinds of variations.

column1: The name of the city was altered several times through the centuries. It was founded as Stanisławów; but in 1772 transliteration changed to Stanislau
column2: in 1919 to Stanislaviv and again to Stanisławów. In 1939 transliteration changed to Stanislav
column4: in 1944 again to Stanislav. And finally
column5: on November 9
column7: the name was officially changed by the First Secretary Nikita Khrushchev
column8: reportedly as an honour to poet Ivan Franko.

column1: The town of Stanisławów was founded as a fortress in order to protect the Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth from Tatar invasions and to defend the multi-ethnic population of the region in case of armed conflicts such as the Khmelnytsky Uprising of 1648. The fort was originally built next to Zabolotiv village (known since 1435)
column2: and Knyahynyn (1449). The village of Zabolotiv and the land around it were purchased by Andrzej Potocki from another Polish nobleman
column3: Rzeczkowski. Stanisławów was issued by Potocki and his declaration establishing the city with Magdeburg rights on May 7
column4: 1662; but the city and its rights
column5: however
column6: were not recognized by the Polish Crown until August 14
column8: when John Casimir had finally approved it. By 1672
column9: the fortress had been rebuilt from wood to stone
column11: and mortar. Also a new large fortified Potocki palace was erected in the place of an older wood structure. Today this building serves as the military hospital. In the same year Jews were granted the right to become permanent residents
column13: conduct commerce and travel in and out of the city as they pleased.Originally the city was divided into two districts: Tysmenytsia and Halych. Sometime in 1817–1819 the neighbouring village of Zabolottya
column15: was incorporated into the city as a new district
column16: while Tysmenytsia district was divided into Tysmenytsia and Lysets districts. Each district had its main street corresponded with its name: Halych Street (Halych district)
column17: Tysmenytsia Street which today is Independence Street (Tysmenytsia district)
column18: Zabolotiv Street – Mykhailo Hrushevsky Street and Street of Vasylyanok (Zabolottya district)
column19: and Lysets Street – Hetman Mazepa Street (Lysets district). Later the city was split into six small districts: midtown where the rich Catholic population and patricians lived
column23: Halych and Lysets where the plebeians lived.

column2: the Austro-Hungarian Empire collapsed and the Western Ukrainian People's Republic (ZUNR) was proclaimed. In the early months of 1919 (from January to May) the city became a temporary capital of the West Ukrainian National Republic
column3: while still recovering from World War I. All state affairs took place in the building of Dnister Hotel where the Act Zluky (Unification Act) was composed and signed on January 22
column4: 1919 by the Ukrainian People's Republic.  The same year it was subjected to the Polish–Ukrainian and the Romanian-Ukrainian skirmishes eventually being annexed by Poland as part of the Second Polish Republic as the centre of the Stanisławów Voivodeship. It was occupied by the Romanian army for the summer months from May 25 through August 21
column5: 1919. During the Polish–Soviet War in 1920
column6: the Red Army took over the city for a brief period. After the Soviet retreat
column7: Ukrainian troops loyal to Symon Petlura occupied the city for a few days. At this period of history the city was in complete disorder.In the 1939 invasion of Poland by German and Soviet forces
column8: the territory was captured by the Soviets in September 1939 and included into the Ukrainian SSR. Between September 1939 and June 1941
column9: the Soviet regime ordered thousands of inhabitants of the city to leave their houses and move to Siberia
column10: where most of them perished. Numerous people were taken out of the city prison and simply shot outside of the city when Soviet forces were leaving it in 1941. Ivano-Frankivsk was occupied by German forces from July 2
column13: 000 Jews in Stanisławów when it was occupied by the Nazi Germany on July 26
column15: more than 600 educated Poles and most of the city's Jewish population were murdered.In early 1944
column16: the city became part of the Soviet Union and was renamed 'Stanislav'. The Soviets forced most of the Polish population to leave the city
column17: most of them settled in the Recovered Territories. During the post-war period the city was part of the Carpathian Military District housing the 38th Army (70th Motor Rifle Division) that participated in the Operation Dunai.

column1: As is the case with most of Ukraine
column2: the climate is moderate continental with warm summers
column3: and fairly cold winters. The following climate data provided is for the past 62 years. The average number of days with precipitation is 170 spread almost equally throughout a year. Most precipitation takes place during the winter months and least – early fall. Thunderstorms occur mostly in summer months averaging around 25 annually. Ivano-Frankivsk averages about 296 days of fog or misty days with about 24 per month.

column1: The city is situated in the Carpathian region northeast of the mountain range
column2: sitting approximately 120 metres (390 ft) above mean sea level. One of the several main geographical features is the Vovchynets Hill also known as the Vovchynets Mountains. The hill reaches 300-350 metres (1
column3: 150 ft) above the sea level and is part of the Pokuttya Highland (Upland). Around the hill Bystrytsia River branches into Bystrytsia of Nadvirna
column5: and Vorona. The last two rivers serve as a natural border between the Pokuttya Highland and Stanislav Basin. The Vovchynets Hill is located just outside and northeast of Ivano-Frankivsk. Located southeast from the Stanislav Basin in the direction of the Prut Valley is the Khorosnen (Prut-Bystrytsia) Highland. The highest point of that highland is Mount Hostra

column1: The closest neighboring city is Tysmenytsia
column2: less than 10 kilometres (6.2 mi) to the east. Other cities that lie in the radius of 25 to 30 km (16 to 19 mi) are Tlumach (east)
column5: and Halych (north). The city also administers five adjacent villages that surround it: Mykytyntsi

column1: Both city and oblast administrations as well as the regional council are all located in a massive white building on Hrushevsky Street locally known as Bily Dim or Bily Budynok. In front of the building
column2: there is a big open space bordered by Shpytalna Street on the north-east
column4: and Melnychuk Street on the south-west. Next to the building
column5: there is a memorial to the Unification of the Western Ukraine with the rest of Ukraine. The main feature of the memorial is a tall marble stele
column6: the both sides of which are adorned with statues: kamenyar (west) and kobzar (east).

column1: Public transportationThe city of Ivano-Frankivsk has an extensive network of public transport including buses
column3: and taxis. There are nine trolleybus routes and about 52 for regular buses. Some of the routes run beyond the city into nearby villages.

column1: Railway transportationThere is one railway terminal that serves the Ivano-Frankivsk train station. There are also smaller railway stations in adjacent villages
column2: including Uhryniv and Khryplyn. All of them are part of Lviv Railways.
the railway terminal also housed a bus terminal which provided several inter-city bus routes
column3: including some to international destinations. In 2000
column4: construction began on a new bus terminal next to the railway terminus on Zaliznychna Street. Inauguration of the new bus terminal took place on 22 May 2010. At the opening ceremony the Mayor of the city
column5: Viktor Anushkevychus
column6: noted that the new bus terminal was only partially completed
column7: and for a period it would be necessary to offload passengers at the Pryvokzalna Square
column8: which is already saturated with traffic. He also emphasised the need for another bus station on the outskirts of the city.

column1: Airways transportationThe city is served by Ivano-Frankivsk International Airport
column2: which was granted international status in 1992. The airport shares its facilities with the 114 Brigade of the Ukrainian Air Force. Since 2002
column3: the airport has been leased to the private enterprise company Yavson
column4: and from 2005 the Public limited company Naftokhimik Prykarpattia
column5: a (subsidiary of Ukrnafta). The contract with Naftokhimik Prykarpattia expired in 2013.

column1: Ivano-Frankivsk is home to a number of sports teams. Most notably
column2: it was home to the football club FC Spartak Ivano-Frankivsk (Prykarpattya) that participated on the national level since the 1950s. Since 2007
column3: the club only fields its youth team Spartak-93 and competes in the Children-Youth Football League of Ukraine. The former president of Spartak Anatoliy Revutskiy reorganized the local university (University of Oil and Gas) team in 2007 into the new "FSK Prykarpattia" with support of the city mayor Anushkevychus making it the main football club in the region and replacing Spartak. Previously during the interbellum period
column4: the city was home to another football club based on the local Polish garrison and called Rewera Stanisławów (1908). That club competed at a regional level that had evolved at that period. With the start of World War II
column5: that club was disbanded. During the Soviet period among several others there was another club "Elektron" that successfully participated at a regional level around the 1970s.

column1: The city also is the home to a futsal team
